titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Fidelis Zitterbart Manuscripts, 1868-1915 SC.1967.02
titlestmt.author: Jim Cassaro.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:03:30 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Fidelis Zitterbart was an active music teacher, performer, and composer from the 1860s through his death in 1915. He was also a member of the New York Theatre orchestra, first violinist with the Theodore Thomas Orchestra, concertmaster of the Strakosch Opera orchestra, and a member of the Brooklyn and New York Philharmonic societies. This collection contains Zitterbart's manuscript compositions for many different musical genres. Digital reproductions are online.
did.langmaterial: The material in this collection is in English and German.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of the collection are available online.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Ralph Zitterbart in May 1960.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Jim Cassaro, Sam Siskind, William Daw, Lisa Campbell, and Sarah Jones during 2012-2015.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Fidelis Zitterbart was born April 9, 1845 in Pittsburgh, Pa., to Fidelis Sr. and Frederica Zitterbart. His father was well-known as a violinist, but also as a conductor and composer who came to the United States as a member of a troupe of instrumentalists from Prague, one of many European musical organizations who saw in this country an untapped audience. When this troupe was disbanded in 1837 without ever completing its tour, Fidelis Sr., after stays in New York and New Orleans, decided to settle in Pittsburgh. The family occupied a small house on 10th Street in Pittsburgh's South Side neighborhood, where Fidelis Jr. was born; his father was his first music teacher. At age 9, Fidelis Jr. became one of the violinists in his father's orchestra, and at this time began to put his musical ideas on paper.

Fidelis Jr. worked with local teachers until the age of 16, when like many musical prodigies, he was sent to Europe to continue his studies. Departing New York in 1861, he travelled to Dresden to continue his violin studies with François Schubert (1808-1878), and theory and keyboard with Julius Rühlmann (1816-1877). Fidelis returned to the United States in 1863 and stayed in New York City where he was a member of several premier musical organizations, including his father's New York Theatre orchestra, first violinist with the Theodore Thomas Orchestra, concertmaster of the Strakosch Opera orchestra, and a member of the Brooklyn and New York Philharmonic societies.

In 1873, Fidelis returned to Pittsburgh as an instructor at Andrew Williams's American Conservatory of Music, located at 41 Fifth Avenue in Downtown Pittsburgh. When the school fell on hard times and closed, Zitterbart opened his own school in the same location, acting as teacher, performer, and composer. He was highly itinerant in Pittsburgh as to dwelling places: he maintained houses in the Hill District (on Crawford and Reed Streets [1874-1877]); Uptown (on Pride and Marion Streets [1878-1911]; in Shadyside (on Summerlea Street [1912-1913]; and finally in Highland Park on North Highland Avenue [1915]. He passed away on August 30, 1915 and was interred in Allegheny Cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The collection contains approximately 1,500 music compositions, all in Fidelis Zitterbart's hand. Many of the scores feature Zitterbart's personal calligraphy in the noting of titles, often with pasted-over images that were evocative of the music's meaning to the composer. The scores are notated in both blue and black ink and sometimes in pencil, on standard 14-stave lined sheets in upright format, or in oblong format. Emendations by the composer appear in ink and/or pencil. The paper, produced in the late nineteenth- and early-twentieth centuries is acidic, often brittle. The collection has been digitized to allow for greater access to researchers as well as to limit the need to access the fragile original materials. Few, if any of the works in the collection were ever commercially published. In processing this collection, we respected the original order in which the manuscripts were received. However, whenever a work is in a particular musical genre (suites, sonatas, duos, quartets, etc.) and is also numbered by the composer, we rearranged these items to bring them together for ease of discoverability.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The following musical genres may be found in the box ranges listed:
10. Sonatas (One String Instrument and Piano): Box 27–30
12. Suites (One or more instruments and piano): Box 2–3

did.physdesc: violino part (9 p.) (2 copies), violoncello part (9 p.) (2 copies) and piano part (25 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Two copies of parts for violin and violoncello. The earlier violin part has an ossia in the 2nd movement (Allegro con brio) for measures 12-17 in pencil at the bottom of the first page. The later violin part has the change in ink in the part. At end of violoncello part: J. Wightmann, copyist, 181 Mulberry St., near Broom[piece missing]. On cover of parts: To Mr. Theodore Thomas. On cover is stamped: Charles B. Weis, instructor of music, Duquesne University. VERY brittle. Violin part badly stained. Location: New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Contents: 1. Ein Wiegenlied (Eb major; dated 09/26/1893) -- 2. Norwegier Wiegenlied (Bb major; dated 10/16/1893) -- 3. Ein Wiegenlied (G minor; dated 12/26/1893) -- 4. Wiegenlied (F major; dated 12/25/1893) -- 5. Wiegenlied (C major; dated 01/16/1894) -- 6. Wiegenlied (G major; dated 01/23/1894) -- 7. Wiegenlied (Ab major; dated 04/03/1894) -- 8. Wiegenlied (E major; dated 04/18/1894) -- 9. Wiegenlied (F major; dated 04/24/1894) -- 10. Wiegenlied (A major; dated 04/25/1894) -- 11. Wiegenlied (A major; dated 06/04/1894).

did.unittitle: Quartett : [no.] 39 for 2 Violins, Viola and Violoncello in D Minor
did.physdesc: 1 score (27 p.), violin 1 part (7 p.), violin 2 part (7 p.), viola part (7 p.), and violoncello part (7 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The number "369" written in pencil on cover. Score has numbers written in blue pencil (rehearsal numbers?), as well as in parts. Some parts have suggested bowings and articulations written in pencil. An extract from the Wall Street Journal (November 30, 1931) is laid in, and compares string quartets to baseball fans. Alternate reading of the last 9 mm of the 1st movement in the Violin I part laid in. Contents: 1. Allegro-maestoso et vigoroso -- 2. Adagio-fantastique et adagio-amoroso -- 3. Scherzo presto -- 4. Finale: Allegro agitato.

did.unittitle: Quintett : [no.] 17 for 2 Violins, 2 Violas, and Violoncello in G Major, The Legend of the White Canoe, Niagara Falls
did.physdesc: 1 score (44 p.), violin 1 part (7 p.), violin 2 part (7 p.), viola 1 part (7 p.), viola 2 part (7 p.), and violoncello part (7 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The number "17" typed on outer wrapper and pasted in on parts. Score written in pencil. Title varies: on outer wrapper, Violin I part, and t.p. of score is "The Legend of Niagara Falls" with "White Canoe" inserted; on score caption is "The Legend of Niagara Falls. At head of Violin I part, "Please return MS to Mr. A.E. Braun, Personal, c/o Farmers Deposit National Bank, Pittsburgh, Pa." Illustration of a bare-breasted Native American woman manuevering a canoe through rapids pasted on Violin I part; postcard with same image mounted on inside cover of Violin I part. Includes 2 concert programs: The Shapiro Quartet (with Edward Engel, second viola) on April 15, 1937 at the University Club in which this piece was performed; and an April 25, 1935 program from The Musicians Club of Pittsburgh at the Pittsburgh Musical Institute Auditorium devoted solely to Zitterbart's chamber music.

did.unittitle: Sonate : [no.] 2 for Violin and Piano in F Major
did.physdesc: 2 scores (17, and 22 p.), and 2 violine parts, (each 6 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The number "23" written in pencil on t.p. The composer has rearranged the movements of the work: in the score, Movement 3, Scherzando is corrected in pencil as movement 4; the new movement 3, Scherzo is in pencil and laid inside the score; in the violin part, movement 2, Adagio is corrected as movement 3; and movement 3 (scherzando in score) is corrected as movement 4 and renamed Allegro giojoso; there is no separate violin part for the new movement 3; that part is only in the ms score. The score has numerous corrections mainly to the piano part in pencil and black ink. Date at the end of the score is 11/03/1888. There is an undated 2nd copy of the piece with the number "2" pasted on the t.p. It has the correct names for each movement, but movement 2 is copied after movement 3 in violin part.

did.unittitle: Die Jungfrau von Orleans : Tongemälde (nach Schiller) : für Streich Quartett
did.physdesc: violine 1 part (5 p.), violine 2 part (4 p.), viola part (4 p.), and violoncello part (4 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Contents: Auf dem Felde. 1. Schuldlos trieb ich meine Lämmer ; Auf des stillen Berges Höh -- 2. Der Feldruf hör ich mächtig zu mir dringen ; Das Schlachtross steigt, und die Trompeten klingen -- Zum Gefängniss. 3. Hör mich O Gott in meine höchsten Noth ; Hinauf zu dir, in heißem Flehenswunsch ; In deine Himmel send ich meine Seele -- 4. Kurz ist der Schmerz und ewig ist die Freude.

did.physdesc: 1 score (44 p.), flute part (9 p.), violin part 1 (8 p.), and violin 2 part (8 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Photograph of 3 men pasted on front cover. "In A major" on flute part. Contents: Reverie -- On the country road -- At Zitterbart's spring -- To the falls. Each movement has different instrumentation. The 1st for flute, 2 violins and piano; followed by a solo piano piece subtitled "Evening" unrelated to the chamber version. The 2nd for flute, 2 violins and piano, followed by a piano piece with flute obligato subtitled "Morning" unrelated to the chamber version. The 3rd for violin and piano. The 4th for flute, 2 violins and piano.

Zitterbart, Jr. Written in black ink on t.p. and dated 2/2/1894 : Presented to Carl Braun for the 22nd anniversary of his birthday, from his teacher Prof. F. Zitterbart, Jr. At head of title on part: In memoriam of Robert Knox ("To Robert Knox et Memoriam written in pencil below and crossed out). Copyright 1894 at bottom of part. did.physdesc: 3 versions, (each 3 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Three versions of the same piece. First and second versions differ in note values and some melodic variation. The number "4" written in pencil on caption of 1st version. The 3rd version (possibly the original?) has numerous corrections and additions in pencil. Title in ink on this version given as: McKinely and Hobart : Inaugural March which is crossed out in pencil and March (Liberty) written in.

did.physdesc: 1 score (9 p.), also 1 handwritten score flute part (1 p.), oboe part (1 p.), clarinet 1 part (1 p.), clarinet 2 part (1 p.), bassoon 1 part (1 p.), bassoon 2 part (1 p.), horn 1 part (1 p.), horn 2 part (1 p.), timpani part (1 p.), violin 1 part (3 copies, each 1 p.), violin 2 part (2 copies, each 1 p.), viola part (2 copies, each 1 p.), violoncello part (2 copies, each 1 p.), and bass part (2 copies, each 1 p.) violin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Very brittle. 2 copies of score. Copy 1 is the final copy in black ink. Oblong format. On cover in pencil: unfinished. At head of title: Meinem Freund William Spriestersbach gewidmet. At end of score is the manuscript in pencil for Air varia for violin and piano ([3] p.). Copy 2 is the fair copy in pencil with original title: Midnight (scratched out and Balcony scene written in). Subtitle given as "Dramatic Music". Following score is the sketches for the 2nd movement, titled "Morning," which is crossed out in black ink. Manuscript parts have title: Midnight, Garden scene.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Two copies of the score. The 1st copy is bound; on verso of the t.p. in pencil: Pittsburgh Exposition Sept 8 '16. The 2nd copy is in oblong format and is a working copy in both black ink and pencil, and sketches at end, and is very brittle. Inside 2nd score is pasted an excerpt from a concert program that featured the work. It also indicates on the cover that the poetry that inspired the work is by Andrew Williams. On the cover of both scores: To [my cousin] Mr. Edmund Schenck.

Minuet (The antique) -- 4. Romance -- 5. Finale: Scherzo-presstissimo.

scopecontent.p: The number "556" written in pencil on cover. The number "10" is pasted in on t.p. The number "6" pasted on caption of score and part. At head of title: To Miss Florence Zitterbart. Only no. 8-10 are dated. Contents: 1. Allegretto -- 2. Presto -- 3. Andante cantabile -- 4. Allegro giojoso -- 5. Traumgebilde: Andante amoroso -- 6. Morceau: Amongst the roses -- 7. Album leaves -- 8. Allegro spiritoso (09/22/1907) -- 9. Song without words: Rememberance (09/24/1907) -- 10. Andante moso-grazioso et molto espressione (10/02/1907).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Incidental music. Includes text written in the score. Libretto by William Heeren. Contents. Ouverture -- Erster Auftritt. Bass aria (Das Bier war heute sehr famos) -- 2ter Auftritt. Soprano solo: Gretchen (Der Haus der spricht schon lange) -- 3tes Auftritt. Recitative. Gretel und Hans -- No. 4. Duett. Hans und Gretchen (Ja ja das ist gar fein erdacht so wird) -- No. 5. Recitative. Hans, Gretel, Wirth) -- No. 6. Gretels Arie ([unreadable text] Stunde bringen Freud oder Leid) -- No. 7. Finale. Terzett. Gretl, Hans und Wirth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Date on t.p.: 03/13/1892, but wrapper and parts all give date as 03/30/1892. Illustration (in color) of Columbus taking possession of the New World. New ending (Einlage) given on pp. 32-35. Text pasted in on caption: Columbus described three mermaids which he himself saw floating on the waves. Many other early navigators give similar accounts.

daodesc.p: Ouverture : Columbus - Parts: Violoncello 2 and 3: March 13, 1892

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Given the number of parts, Zitterbart must have conceived this work for string ensemble in 5 parts, not for string quintet with one on a part. Outer wrapper labeled "Volkwein's."

scopecontent.p: Illustrated t.p. Alternate instrumentation written in in pencil on t.p. On inner t.p. the word "Septett" is added to the title. The oboe part is written in pencil below the flute line in the score. At head of inner t.p.: To Miss Elizabeth Breese. Contents: 1. Andante grazioso -- 2. Valse de Parisienne -- 3. Swansong allegretto-con-moto -- 4. Intermezzo (Under the sycamore tree) -- 5. Finale: Allegro-con-moto.

did.unittitle: Fantasie : [no.] 6 : The Poacher's Dream : for Violin, Viola [and] Piano : [in F major]
did.physdesc: 1 score (15 p.), violin part (3 p.), and viola part (3 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Given the placement of this work in numerical order with the other Reverie und Fantasie, it seems that Zitterbart meant for it to be titled as such. Subtite on score and parts: In Suite Form. The number "6" pasted in on score and parts. The number "331" penciled in on t.p. Narrative pasted in on verso of cover. Contents: 1. The dreaming poacher -- 2. The hunt -- 3. The vision -- 4. The duel -- 5. The promenade -- 6. Finale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Given the placement of this work in numerical order with the other Reverie und Fantasie, it seems that Zitterbart meant for it to be titled as such. Subtite on score and parts: In Suite Form. The number "7" pasted in on score and parts. The number "330" penciled in on score. Narrative pasted in at end of score. Contents: 1. The statue -- 2. Lifes breath -- 3. Weird fancies -- 4. The statues embrace -- 5. Finale: The sculptures death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Score is in oblong format and written in ink, with numerous corrections by the composer in pencil. The opening 4 pages are noted as "Neue Introduction." Original opening is titled "Ouverture (Die Sage);" written in pencil following this is: "Siehe neu Introduction Die Sage." At head of titel: Aufgeführt im Verein Frohsin zu Pittsburgh. Contents. 1. Ouverture et introduction -- 2. Schlummerlied -- 3. Cinderellas Bild -- 4. Hansel und Gretel -- 5. Gebet -- 6. Däumlings Marsch -- 7. Der Sängerkrieg (komisch).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: At head of title: Volksstücke [no.] I. The number "419" written in pencil on cover. "Opus 125" written in red ink on cover. Date of composition at end of Violin I part: 8/10/1875. No part for piano included. Contents: In the factory -- The fire alarm -- The rush to the fire -- To the concert -- Ein piano solo (theme and variations) -- In the quiet of the night -- The break of day -- March of the Duquesne Greys -- To the singing society -- A song with a mistake -- A short dance -- The serenade -- Good night.

daodesc.p: Reverie Orientale : in E Minor : a la Barcarolle : [for] Piano: September 20, 1902

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The number "3" pasted in on caption. Original (?) title on caption: Barcarolle (Reverie orientale), but crossed out in black ink. Steiner renamed the work. On caption: "Edited by W.K. Steiner." Facsimile of the composer's manuscript with Steiner's revisions in pen; with erasures. Note attached to first page: "The original violin bowing has been scratched out and "sense" bows put in. Pieces edited in the old fashioned way are made twice as difficult to relay as they really are on account of the wrong impression given by violin bowing."

did.unittitle: One Night at Richters : Popular Musical Sketch : for Orchestra
did.physdesc: flute and piccolo part (3 p.), oboe part (3 p.), clarinet in C part (4 p.), horn part (3 p.), cornet in B part (3 p.), trombone part (3 p.), percussion part (small drum, bass drum, triangle, champagne corks, bells, sandblocks, tam tam) (3 p.), separate triangle part (1 p.), violin 1 part (2 copies, each 4 p.), violin 2 part (2 copies, each 3 p.), viola part (4 p.), violoncello part (3 p.), and bass part (3 p.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Contents: 1. Quickstep to Richters -- 2. Song of the witch from operetta Hans & Gretel -- 3. Penny Press past edition -- 4. The girl I left behind -- 5. Train in the distance -- 6. Temperance women entrance -- 7. Entrance of 2 reverend gentlemen -- 8. The blind fiddler and colored bone player -- 9. Fire alarm -- 10. A champagne treat -- 11. When the moon on the lake is beaming -- 12. City Hall song.

scopecontent.p: Subtitle on parts: In form of Salon pieces. Contents: 1. The serenade -- 2. Allegretto (The mill) -- 3. Allegro vivace (The Halloween mask) -- 4. Adagio cantabile (Wild roses) -- 5. Andante con Moto (In Dreamland) -- 6. Finale (Marcia heroique) -- 7. Allegretto (Floating) -- 8. Moderato Deciso (The controversy) -- 9. Presto (The ogre) -- 10. Andante calmato (A dolls lullaby) -- 11. Scherzo presto (Merry youths) -- 12. Minuet (Majestic) Illustration of a woman in a veil pasted on cover.

Illustration (black & white) of "The Village Wedding" pasted on t.p. Contents: 1. Introduction: Moderato sostenuto (At the altar and the gathering) -- 2. Adagio-cantabile et molto-esspressione (The bride) -- 3. Allegro-Spiritoso (The dance at the inn) -- 4. Finale: Allegro-con-moto et spiritoso (The wedding feast).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Score bound upside down in wrapper; Subtitle on cover: Or Risen from the dead; At head of title: Dedicated respectfully to Mr. L. Newton Gotthold (the author). Quotes Robert Schumann in Clarinet part: Ich bitte sie um alle Heiligen willen spielen sie schmähtend
